body.header:
Read the writing task and look carefully at the bar chart. Complete the report by choosing the word, phrase or number which best fits each gap.
Writing Task 1

section.p: The chart compares the attendance of Canadians of different agesincomesinterests at live arts performances. There is clearly a strong relationship between age and the sort of events people attend.

The figures show that almost halfhalfjust over half of Canadian teenagers frequently go to live arts events and that they are almost twicehalfthree times as likely to attend such performances as Canadians who are 60 or over. Not surprisingly, the greatest difference in attendance figures is for pop concertstheatrical performancesopera. The 15 to 19 age group is almost five timestwiceten times as likely as the over 60s to attend such concerts. Likewise, the proportion of Canadians who go to theatre, opera and dancesymphonic or classical musicchoral music performances falls as age increases.

In contrast, the proportion who go to classical and choral music performances rises as age increases. Approximately 1 in 101 in 41 in 3 Canadians who are 60 or over go to classical concerts. This percentage is almost twice as highas highthree times as high as that for teenagers.

Attendance rates vary the least for theatre and opera performances. Only about a fiftha tentha quarter of all age groups attend the theatre frequently. Similarly, a very small percentagequantitynumber of any age group go to the opera regularly.
In summary, audiences at Canadian performing arts events seem to be mainly young people attending plays or pop concerts.
2. 47.2 per cent, which is almost half.
3. 47.2 per cent for teenagers compared to almost 25 per cent for the oldest age group.
4. It's not surprising that pop concerts are much more popular with younger age groups.
5. Compare just over 7 per cent for the over-60s to nearly 35 per cent for teenagers.
6. As with pop music, dance performances are more popular with younger people.
7. 8.3 per cent, which is approximately 1 in 10.
8. Compare just over 8 per cent for the over-60s with just over 5 per cent for teenagers.
9. The percentages range from about 17 per cent for the over-60s to about 22 per cent for teenagers, which is about a fifth.
10. We don't normally use 'quantity' to refer to people.
In fact, the chart doesn't tell us the actual numbers involved. We don't know if the numbers are small or large.
